turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We will hear argument first this morning in 79-983, United States v. Will, and 79-1689, United States v. Will.
Mr. Geller, you may proceed whenever you are ready.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:

These consolidated cases are direct appeals by the Government from the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois which declared unconstitutional four Acts of Congress that were passed in consecutive years between 1976 and 1979 to hold down or eliminate annual cost-of-living salary increases for all high-ranking federal officials, including the Vice President, Members of Congress, Cabinet and sub-Cabinet officials in the Executive Branch, and federal judges.
The District Judge held that to the extent these pay freeze statutes applied to judges, they violated the compensation clause of Article III of the Constitution.
The District Court also held that as a matter of statutory construction the statutes were not intended by Congress to be substantive legislation.

That is, they were not intended to wipe out the federal officials' entitlement to a cost-of-living increase but were instead only appropriations measures that refused to provide the money for salary increases required by law.
The Government in these appeals has challenged each of these holdings.

Before setting forth the facts that led to these lawsuits I think it would be helpful to begin by briefly explaining the somewhat complicated mechanism by which the pay of federal judges is determined.
For the first 180 years of our Nation's history, judicial salaries were fixed by Congress essentially on an ad hoc basis.
During this period Congress raised the salaries of Supreme Court Justices on 12 occasions and raised the salaries of lower court judges on nine occasions.
Congress finally changed this system in 1967 by passing the Federal Salary Act.

Under this Act the salaries of federal judges as well as the Vice President, Members of Congress, Cabinet officers, and selected other high level officials are reviewed by a blue ribbon commission every four years to determine appropriate pay levels.

This commission reports its findings to the President who must submit to Congress in his next budget message recommendations for the exact rate of pay for these officials, and then within 60 days both Houses of Congress must vote on the President's recommendations.
The first federal salary act review took place in fiscal year 1969 and the review process has occurred every four years since then.

In fact, just last week the membership of the fiscal 1981 review commission was announced and that commission is scheduled to make its report to the President on increases in judicial and other salaries by the end of this calendar year.
Now, the Federal Salary Act contains no mechanism for annual adjustments of salaries of the officials covered by that Act.
Rather, the only means specified in the Salary Act for modifying such salaries is the quadrennial review process.
In an attempt to remedy this problem Congress in 1975 passed the Executive Salary Cost-of-Living Adjustment Act.
This Act applies, by and large, to the officials covered by the Federal Salary Act, including federal judges.

Now, under the Adjustment Act judicial salaries are subject to an annual increase equal to the annual percentage cost-of-living increase given to civil service employees in that year, pursuant to yet another statute, the Federal Pay Comparability Act of 1970.
Under The Comparability Act the President each year must designate a pay agent to compare civil service salaries with the rates of pay for the same levels of work in private industry.
Following the study the pay agent submits his report to the President along with a recommendation of appropriate adjustments in civil service rates of pay.
After considering this report the President has two options.

First, he can inform Congress that he agrees with and adopts the agent's recommendation, in which event the recommended cost-of-living increase automatically goes into effect as of the first pay period after October 1st of that year.

On the other hand, if because of a national emergency or economic conditions affecting the general welfare the President believes that the pay agent's recommendations are too high, the President may reject the pay agent's recommendation and submit an alternative pay raise plan to Congress.
If neither House of Congress disapproves the President's alternative plan, it goes into effect on the first pay period after October 1st.
However, if the House or the Senate disapproves the President's alternative plan within 30 days, then the original recommendation of the pay agent goes into effect for civil service employees.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: And that can be downward as well as upward?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: The President's recommendation could conceivably be downwards, and generally it is downwards rather than upward.

Now, as I mentioned earlier, the Adjustment Act ties the cost-of-living increases of high-ranking federal officials including federal judges to the average cost-of-living increase given to civil servants under the Comparability Act.
In addition the Adjustment Act specifies the effective date of any such adjustment for judges as of October 1st of each year.
So, to summarize, judicial pay is determined by reference to three separate statutes.
There is the Federal Salary Act which sets a base pay for judges with a review of that base every four years.

And then there's the Adjustment Act which provides that judges may get an annual cost-of-living increase measured by the cost-of-living increase given to civil service employees under the Comparability Act, and the Adjustment Act increase goes into effect... if there is one... on October 1st of the year.
Now, the first year the Adjustment Act was in effect was 1975, and in October, 1975, civil service salaries were increased by an average of five percent pursuant to the Comparability Act.
And as a result, federal judges and other officials covered by the Adjustment Act received a like increase.
The events that led to these lawsuits began in the fall of 1976.
In October, 1976, the salaries of civil service employees were increased by an average of 4.8 percent under the Comparability Act.

On September 22, 1976, however, the House and Senate passed a bill which was signed by the President on October 1st providing that none of the funds appropriated in any statute could be used to pay the salary of any official covered by the Adjustment Act at a rate that exceeded the salary in effect for that official on September 30th, 1976.

In other words, this statute which we've referred to in this litigation as the 1976 Pay Act prevented the 1976 Adjustment Act increases from taking effect for federal judges and a number of other high level officials.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Geller, what was the basis of the District of Court's jurisdiction?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: The Tucker Act.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Would the Government be in a better position here if the Tucker Act had been repealed or never been enacted?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Well, there would be some question whether judges would have a right to sue because they're claiming under the Compensation Clause of the Constitution.
Just like, for example, the Just Compensation Clause in the Fifth Amendment might well require that Congress provide some judicial remedy, but it's certainly not an issue in this case.
We have not challenged the District Court's jurisdiction.
It clearly falls under 28 U.S.C. 1346 (a)(2).
Now, in each of the next three years after 1976 Congress passed a separate pay act to limit or eliminate the anticipated Adjustment Act increase for that year.
In July 1977 Congress passed the 1977 Pay Act which provided that the cost-of-living increases that would have become effective in October, 1977, "shall not take effect".
The reason Congress did this was because in March of 1977 the officials covered by the Adjustment Act had received their quadrennial salary increase pursuant to the Salary Act.

Federal judges, for example, had gotten a pay raise of almost 30 percent under the Salary Act in March, 1977, and there was substantial sentiment in Congress that high-ranking federal officials should not get two pay increases in the course of a single year.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Now, this deals with the 4.8 that might otherwise have become effective on October 1... what?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Well, actually, I was just referring to the 1977 legislation which wiped out--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well, the 29-whatever-that-percentage-was, that became effective when?
March of '77?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --That became... March of '77, that's right.
Now in October of 1977 civil service employees got a 7.2 percent increase under the Comparability Act.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well, do we have any case here that involves the 4.8-whatever-that-percentage-was, effective in October of '76, or is that--

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Yes, that is in this case.
That is Count 1 of the Will I.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: --And you just said that the increase in 29-whatever-it-was that became effective in March of '77--

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: --what bearing did that have on the 4.8?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: That set a new base salary level for judges.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: And in doing that did Congress supersede whatever the increase was, the 4.8?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Well, no.

The only bearing that the 4.8 percent has in this litigation now is, if appellees are correct that Congress could not wipe out the 4.8 percent then the judges would be entitled to back pay for the period from October 1, 1976.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: What you're saying is, Congress meant to eliminate that 4.8 in light of the 29 that became effective in March, '77?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Well, what Congress meant to eliminate in light of the 30 percent increase judges got was the 7.2 percent salary increase--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: That's what I'm trying to get to.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: And it had no bearing on the 4.8?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Only in the sense that the base salary had been paid.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: No, what I'm trying to get at is, did Congress say anything in respect to the 29-point... that it was supersede any of the 4.8?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: But there are a number of statements in the legislative history that talk about superseding the 7.2 percent that was going to become effective in October of '77 because it would have been two salary increases in one year.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, then, you don't think, then, that that quadrennial increase was effective to wipe out any entitlement to any prior cost-of-living increases?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Well, it only became effective in March, 1977.
What it does wipe out is any claim that judges have to a new base salary level based on the 4.8 percent, but what it doesn't wipe out is back pay for the period October 1, 1976, to March, 1977.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: If they were entitled to it?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: If they were entitled to it.
That's what I'm saying.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: I see.
Well, so your answer to my question is, for the future, it does take the place of any future entitlement to the 4.8 after October 1?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: That's right.
As far as base salary levels are concerned--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: I got it.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --the only relevance it has to this lawsuit is the back pay issue.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So it did effect a permanent disentitlement to the 4.8 percent?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: As a continuing matter.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, all right; fine.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Geller, let me get this clear.
You did just say that the 4.8, in any event, in light of the 29 percent that became effective in March, '77, limited the 4.8 to the period from October 1, '76, to March, '77?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: That's right.
That is the relevance in this lawsuit.
It's simply a matter of back pay, it's not a question of increasing base salary levels because that was accomplished in March, 1977, with the Salary Act increase.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, your brief doesn't make this clear, but it's... but that's wholly consistent with your position, I must say.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Just as if the current salary, the current quadrennial review process that's now beginning will set a new salary level for judges, presumably, unless the President or Congress doesn't go along with the recommendations.

It will set a new salary level for judges as of March or April, 1981, and therefore all of these prior pay acts will be relevant only in terms of back pay and not in terms of setting a new salary level for judges--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Provided that the new level is higher than the percentages involved?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --Providing that it is, yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: If it's not, of course, then the issue will remain.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: All right.
Yet... Mr. Geller, in reviewing the fairly complicated statutory system under which judicial salaries are determined, did you mention the basic statute, 28 U.S.C. Section 135?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Well, that just sets the base salary for district judges.
There's a separate statute that sets the salary for each level of the Federal judiciary, Section 135 is for district judges, and what it does is, it has two components.
It says a base salary, plus, you know, the Adjustment Act increase the base salaries, the salary--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: "As adjusted, each judge"... and this is the district judge...
"shall receive a salary at an annual rate determined under the Federal Salary Act, as adjusted by the Executive Salary Cost-of-Living Adjustment Act. "

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --Right.
As I said, there are two components to judicial salary.
One is--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: That is the statutory salary that a judge receives.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --Well, that is the statute that sets forth the components of a judge's salary and it refers to other statutes.
It refers to the Federal Salary Act and it refers to the Adjustment Act.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: It says, "Each judge shall receive" that salary.
You didn't mention that, did you?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Well, I don't even mention that because there's a separate statute for each branch of the federal judiciary, and all it does is relate how all the other statutes work.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, that's all it does, but it does do that.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Yes.
Well, there is a separate statute in that event for each judge.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: That language is mandatory, is it not?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: That is the salary that a district judge gets as provided in Section 135.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: And then there's a separate statute for circuit judges and--

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Circuit judges, Supreme Court Justices, and for other parts of the federal judiciary.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: --But each one is similar, or is it?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: That's right.
The language is similar.

Well, just to finish up the statement of facts, in September of 1978 Congress eliminated a 5.5 percent pay raise for Adjustment Act employees that would have gone into effect on October 1st of that year.
And last year, on October 12, 1979, Congress reduced the Adjustment Act increase for fiscal year 1980 from 12.9 percent to 5.5 percent.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Geller, for a moment, on the September 30, '78, statute, is that the only one of these statutes in which Congress expressly limited the effect of the statute to the then, to the year involved?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: No--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It says,
"No part of the fund appropriated hereby shall be used to pay salaries for this period-- "
Is that language repeated in the other statutes or is it?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --Yes.

Except for the... it's repeated in all of the statutes except in the 1977 statute which is not part of an appropriations act at all and simply says that the October, 1977, Adjustment Act increases shall not take effect.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Each of the Acts by its terms applies only to one year.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Now, is that the Act that was signed by the President late in the afternoon of October 1?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: No, I'm just talking about the 1979.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: I know that.
I thought you mentioned also the '77?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: No, the '76 Act was signed on October 1st.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: And was signed but... sometime later in the day of October 1st?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Well, sometime on October 1st.
I don't know what time of day it was signed.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: But it was substantially after midnight, or one minute after--

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: I assume that it was not signed substantially after--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: --And that presents a question about your--

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --There is a question--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: --Under the diminution clause in there.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --That's correct.
There is a question which I would hope to get to a little bit later of what the effect is of the bills that took the... the Act that took effect on October 1st?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, Mr. Geller, as part of the facts... I take it this is part of the facts... on October 1, 1979, the Government seems to agree, at least in its brief, that the October 1 increase did go into effect--

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --along with the increase that had been suspended for the prior year.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So that it's for a total of 12.9 percent--

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: 12.9 percent.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --did go into effect?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Yes.
And there's no question in this case about the judges' entitlement to the 12.9 percent for the 12 days.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Or for any other part of the Executive Branch or not?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Or for any other part of the Executive Branch although, just to complicate matters further for officials other than judges, salary doesn't take effect on October 1st but on the first pay period after October 1st.
So that--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I see; I see.
I understand.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --Appellees representing the classes of federal judges affected by these pay acts brought these actions under the Tucker Act in February, 1978, and October, 1979.
The first suit which we've referred to as Will I challenged the 1976 and 1977 Pay Acts as reducing judicial compensation in violation of the Compensation Clause.
In the second suit, which has been referred to as Will II, presented the identical challenge to the 1978 and 1979 Pay Acts.
The District Court agreed with appellees and declared all four statutes unconstitutional.

According to the District Court, once the Adjustment Act became law in 1975, then the right to an annual cost of living increase measured by the average cost-of-living adjustment given to civil servants under the Comparability Act became part of the judges' compensation which may never thereafter be diminished or eliminated.

In addition, as I noted earlier, the district judge also concluded as an alternative holding that the Pay Acts were merely appropriations measures that refused to fund but did not wipe out the Adjustment Act increases for each of the four years in question.

The United States believes that each of these holdings is incorrect but before I discuss what we view as the errors in the District Court's opinion, there are two procedural matters that the Court has directed the parties to address.
The first is the question of jurisdiction.

The Court postponed consideration of the question of jurisdiction until the hearing on the merits, but we don't think there's any question that this Court has appellate jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C. 1252.
The District Court held unconstitutional several Acts of Congress in a civil action to which the United States is a party.
Hence, a direct appeal lies to this Court under Section 1252.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, did the District court have jurisdiction?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: It had jurisdiction under the Tucker Act.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Even if the judge was disqualified?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Well, I'm now going to get to the question of his qualifications.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But let's assume he was, though.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Assuming he was disqualified, we don't view the question of disqualification as jurisdictional in nature.
The District Court clearly had jurisdiction under the Tucker Act.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: In which event we would have appellate jurisdiction?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Exactly.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Even if we were disqualified?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: That is our view.
We don't view the recusal statute as being jurisdictional in nature.
The court clearly has jurisdiction, although there may be a separate question as to which judge of that court should hear the case.
Now, as I said, a somewhat related question concerns the disqualification of the members of this Court and the District Court.
These cases obviously directly involve the pay of federal judges.

Moreover, each of the Justices of this Court is a member of the plaintiff classes certified by the district judge in Will I and Will II, and the District Judge was himself a member of the certified class in Will II.
Therefore, we believe it's clear that the members of this Court and the District Judge technically have a disqualifying interest within the meaning of the judicial recusal statute, 28 U.S.C. 455.
Nonetheless, all the parties and amici agree that this is an appropriate instance for invoking the so-called rule of necessity.

Every currently sitting federal judge, whether or not a class member, has a direct and immediate financial interest in the outcome of these cases and would therefore seem to be equally disqualified under 28 U.S.C. 455 (b)(4).
In these circumstances we believe the Court as it did a half-century ago in the income tax cases can and should decide these appeals.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: If you were drawing a disqualification statute for judges, wouldn't this be one of the very first things that you would consider, a case in which they were passing on their own salaries?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Yes, and it is, I think clearly within the judicial recusal statute that... this situation.

Not only do the Justices of this Court have a financial interest in the outcome of these cases, but by virtue of the District Judge's certification of the classes, each member of this Court is a party to the litigation, which is a separate disqualifying factor under the statute.
We don't think there's any dispute among the parties or amici that the judges of this Court technically are disqualified.
We think, however, it's a clear case for invocation of the rule of necessity.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Geller, would you tell me your understanding of, if you had to state the rule.
What is the rule of necessity?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: My understanding is that when every judge is disqualified from hearing a case, then no judge is disqualified simply by virtue of the disqualifying factor.

I should add the obvious that if any Justice feels that he can't personally sit on this case because he cannot be impartial, then that Justice individually should make the decision to disqualify himself.
But we don't think that the Justices of this Court are disqualified simply because they fall within one of the disqualifying factors--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: And this is not a matter of statutory construction, is it?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --Well, I suppose there would be a separate question presented--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Does it appear that Congress ever addressed this question when they drafted that 455?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --There is precious little discussion in the history of it.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: And certainly, on the face of it, it's flat and mandatory that--

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: We think it would have been quite remarkable that Congress would have intended to abrogate the rule of necessity without saying so.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: --Then you are suggesting we read in the rule of necessity?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Yes.
We think that it survives.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Imply it or what?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Well, there were previous judicial recusal statutes before Section 455 and the rule of necessity was applied to them.
We don't think there's anything in the legislative history or the language of--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well, I gather you are saying then that this is a statutory construction question?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --I think it is a common law rule which Congress has not abrogated.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: And so we should say, except where the rule of necessity applies?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And add it on to the statute?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Excuse me.
Again?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: We should add on to the statute an exception?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: I think it's a well recognized exception that was read into all the previous judicial recusal statutes, and, yes, I think the Court should do the same here.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: If all the members of this Court were disqualified under 455, what would be the consequence in terms of the judgments that you're asking to be reviewed?
Would they stand?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: It would depend, Mr. Chief Justice, on why the Court decided that the members of this Court were disqualified.

If the Court were to decide that the rule of necessity has been abrogated and that every federal judge now on the bench is equally disqualified and that no one can hear this case, then we think that the appropriate disposition would be for this Court to vacate the judgment of the District Court who was also equally disqualified.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, if we're disqualified to sit, how can we decide anything?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Well, I think under the same rationale that allows this Court to determine whether it has jurisdiction or even in cases where the Court clearly doesn't have jurisdiction because the issue is moot.
For example, the Court sometimes sends the case back to have the judgment vacated even though technically the Court doesn't have jurisdiction.
Now, however, I should add that--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You told us at the outset that this is not a matter of jurisdiction, I thought?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --That's correct, and why I think I'm consistent in saying that the Court would have the power to send the case back to the District Court with instructions to vacate that judgment.
It seems to us that if every judge is disqualified there's no reason to leave that judgment outstanding.
However, there's another possibility here which I should mention, and that is, the Members of this Court may feel that they are disqualified because they are parties to this litigation.
Now, not every federal judge now on the bench is a party to this litigation.
A judge who was appointed after October 12, 1979, would not be a member of any of the certified classes.

Now, 28 U.S.C. 2109 allows this Court in a case in which there is no quorum, because more than four Justices are disqualified, to remit the case to the appropriate circuit to be heard by a panel of that circuit, and finally determined.

So if this Court decides that the rule of necessity does apply but that the Justices of this Court have a special disqualification because they're members of a class, then I suppose the appropriate disposition would be to send the case back to the 7th Circuit to be heard by a three-judge panel composed of judges who were appointed after October 12, 1979.
But nobody has suggested that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But they would still have a stake in the case.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: They would still have a stake in the case but they wouldn't have this additional disqualification.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: They wouldn't be parties.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: They wouldn't be a party.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, it doesn't matter, does it, if they have a stake in the case, I thought 455 was mandatory disqualification?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: That is our position, Mr. Justice Brennan.
That's why we think this Court should decide the case.
But the Members of this Court have two disqualifications; there are members of the federal judiciary now who only have one disqualification.
If that is deemed relevant by this Court, then there is the option of sending it back to the 7th Circuit.
I'd like to turn, then, to the statutory basis for the District Court's holding.
The court's statutory determination is extremely important for two reasons.

First, if this Court agrees with the District Court that the appellees had a statutory right to their cost-of-living increases over the past four years, then there will be no need to reach the constitutional issues raised by the Pay Acts.
Second, the district judge's statutory holding affects a great many federal employees other than judges.

If the District Court is correct as a matter of statutory construction, then not only judges but about 2,000 other federal employees covered by the Adjustment Act would have gotten salary raises in each of the last four years.

And, in addition, some 20,000 civil servants whose pay is subject to a statutory ceiling pegged to the lowest executive schedule salary level would also be entitled to receive back pay, because the ceiling would have been raised in each of the last four years.
These combined pay increases would total several hundred million dollars.
In light of these two important considerations, the District Court's treatment of the statutory issue is somewhat remarkable.
The issue is discussed in a single paragraph at the very end of its opinion in Will I.
The court merely states that none of the Pay Acts contains any language indicating that it was intended to be anything more than an appropriation statute.

But the 1977 Pay Act, at least, was not an appropriation statute at all, and while the other three Pay Acts were part of appropriations bills, this Court has made clear on several occasions that Congress if it wants to can suspend or repeal substantive legislation in an appropriations act.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Geller, you know, it's a small point, but your opponents take issue with your use of the term "Pay Act".
Is that a term that you just coined for purposes of litigation or does it have any history beyond that?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: It is a term that was coined for the purpose of litigation but not... it's a convenient shorthand.
Each of these acts has a very long name.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Right.
I understand.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: We didn't do it for any tactical litigation purpose, but it is something that we have been using since the--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: That's not a term Congress uses?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --Not a term, although I think in some of those later statutes the term did start to work its way into the legislative history, but it's not a term in the statute itself.
Anyway, as the Court said in Belknap, the whole question depends on the intention of Congress as to whether an appropriation statute was intended to amend or repeal substantive legislation.
Now, the District Court's decision does not discuss the language, the legislative history, or the purpose of any of the Pay Acts.

We have in our brief set forth this legislative history in exhaustive detail, and I don't think it would serve any purpose for me to repeat any of that history here, but I doubt that anyone can read the statements of the Members of the House and the Senate, statement after statement and Pay Act after Pay Act, without concluding that Congress unquestionably intended to prohibit the Adjustment Act increases from going into effect.
There are repeated references to a pay freeze or--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: For that year--

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --For that year; that's right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: --to which it was addressed.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: To which it was addressed; that's correct.
There are repeated references to a pay freeze, or to a pay cap, or to a desire to supersede or rescind the cost of living increases for the year in question.
There's virtually no evidence in the legislative record to the contrary.

In fact, because the whole purpose of the Pay Acts was to hold down the pay of high-ranking federal officials, largely as an anti-inflation measure, it would have defeated Congress's express objectives if the Pay Acts had simply been limitations on expenditures.

What this would have meant is that Congress in four consecutive years merely wanted to withhold funds necessary to meet the Government's acknowledged obligations under the Adjustment Act, but to leave those substantive obligations intact, knowing full well that those obligations could be enforced in Court.
Neither the district judge nor appellees have offered any plausible explanation why Congress would repeatedly have engaged in such a senseless and futile exercise.
Now, if this Court agrees that the Pay Acts were intended to be substantive legislation, then the question remains whether that legislation is constitutional.
The Compensation Clause analysis essentially involves two separate inquiries.
First, were judicial salaries diminished in the constitutional sense by the Pay Acts?
And second, if a diminishment occurred, was it the sort of reduction prohibited by Article III?

It's the Government's position that the 1976, 1977, and 1978 Pay Acts did not diminish appellees' compensation because at the time these statutes were enacted, the annual cost-of-living adjustments allowed by the Adjustment Act had not yet gone into effect.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Do I take it that you have implicitly conceded that the 1979 legislation did reduce the--

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Oh, yes; we've said that in the brief, that it's a reduction in compensation there although there's still--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: --There's no question that it did.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --a second question as to whether it's constitutional.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well, Mr. Geller, whatever the... is it 1977, the one that was not signed until late in the day--

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: What about that?
Was that in effect at midnight of October 1?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: The cases in this Court hold that the general rule in construing legislation is that the courts will not inquire into the time of day that the bill was signed, that it will be presumed to take effect as of the first moment of the day.
Now, appellees correctly point out that there is an exception to this rule; where substantial justice so requires, the courts will inquire into the fractions of the day.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: That's the Louisville case?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: That is one of the many cases--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: And how to you respond to that one?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --That's right, Mr. Justice Blackmun.
We don't think that this is a case in which substantial justice requires the Court to inquire into the time of day that the Act was passed.
It's clear that Congress intended to pass the 1976 Pay Act before October 1st.
It passed both Houses of Congress on September 22.
The President didn't sign it until October 1st only because no one really thought it was crucial that he do so.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: When you speak of whether justice requires it... was that the term?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: "Substantial justice".

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: "Substantial justice".
--do you take into account the equities of the situation?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: I think that's what the Court should take into account.
We think that appellees' hypertechnical argument here does not entitle them to use of this exception to substantial justice.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, would the Court then be permitted to take into account that a United States district judge's salary today is less than half by far of the purchasing power in terms of 1969 dollars?
Is that the kind of inequity?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: I don't think so, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, what kind?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: We're not talking here about the base salaries that judges are entitled to.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: No, but, you speak of equities.
What... I'm puzzled as to what kind of equities you have in mind if that isn't one of them.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Well, what I'm talking about, if the Court decides that the Congress can supersede Adjustment Act increases if it acts before those increases go into effect, and if it decides that those increases go into effect on October 1 of each year as the statute so requires, then it would seem to us not to require resort to the exception to the general rule in order to save the 1976 pay increases to judges.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Geller, is it not true that the general rule and its exception deal with how you construe what Congress intended to do.
It's a construction of the statute rather than its effect?
And it's no question here, they intended that the statute would be effective as of 12:01 a.m.--

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: There's no question about it.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --And the question is, whether the increase in salary having been in effect for several hours, does Article III of the Constitution prevent the President and the Congress from then rescinding that, what had become effective?
And it is true that, say, 9 o'clock in the morning there was a different salary rate in effect, wasn't there?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: In some metaphysical sense.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: At 9 o'clock in the morning, if you were then asked what the salary was, you would have to have said, as of this moment the 4.8 percent has gone into effect, wouldn't you?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: I think that's true, and at 5 o'clock--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And so even if, later on, unambiguously, Congress said, we intend to cut it back as of 12:01 a.m., then the question is, can they do that constitutionally?
None of the cases you've cited deal with a question remotely like this, do they?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --Well, they deal with questions--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Of what the intent of the statute was.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --It was important to determine when an Act took effect.
The Court has said that the test is that it takes effect as of the first moment of the day unless substantial justice--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Purely as a matter of statutory construction, isn't that correct?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --Well, some of those cases, I believe, did involve constitutional questions.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Which one?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: I would have to, while my opponent is speaking give you the names, but they involve questions where penalties were imposed by statutes--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, the ones cited in the footnote to your brief all dealt with the question of statutory construction.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Maybe there others that haven't come to our attention.
Mr. Geller, it isn't in the record, of course, but didn't exactly the same thing happen two weeks ago?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --The 1980 Pay Act was passed on October 1st, that's correct.
Well, that's after--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Was it passed or signed, or both?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --It was both.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: But that's not true of the '76?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: That's right.
The '76 Pay Act was passed well before October 1st.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: If the established rule was, as you argue, that an act is effective on the day it's signed, but retroactive to the previous midnight, I suppose the President might have thought October 1 was the last day he could sign it.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: I think that that's correct.
I think the President this year, and Congress this year, could have thought they could act until October 1, based on the position that Government was taking in these cases.
Appellees contend that--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Of course, on that point, they also thought in '79 that they could wait 12 days, didn't they?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --No, I don't think that there's any question; certainly there's no question--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You think they deliberately acted in an unconstitutional manner?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --No, I don't think that they intended that the 1979 Pay Act apply to the period between October 1 and October 11.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, what about the provision of the statute, if anyone takes the 12.9 percent, there's a waiver of anything... if he takes 5.5 percent, there's a waiver of that right?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: That was meant to imply, I think, prospectively.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Does it say so?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Well, there are... it is not easy to understand what Congress thought it was doing in the 1979 Pay Act by adding in this waiver language, there's not much legislative history either, but there are certain statements on the floor by Representative Whitten in which, what he says is, we intend the 1979 Pay Act, like the previous three Pay Acts, to apply substantively.
However, there is some question in light of Judge Roszkowski's decision in the Will litigation as to whether we can do that.

I don't think there should have been any question on the part of Congress, but Representative Whitten says there may be some question as to whether we can act substantively in an appropriations measure.
And therefore, let's accomplish that purpose essentially by means of a settlement.
Anyone who after today takes the 5.5 percent will be waiving his right to the 12.9 percent.
But I don't think there is any talk about the period retroactively.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: If he took the 5.5 percent sometime later, would he retain or give up the right to 12.9 percent for the 12 days when it was in effect?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Well, we have taken the position that it's not clear from the legislative history.
We have always taken the position that appellees have the right--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes, but these appellees... none of these appellees took the 5.5 percent.
I wonder what would the Government's position be with respect to the consequences of taking the 5.5 percent with respect to the right to the 12.9 percent for 12 days?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --For the 12 days, they would not be waiving their right to the 12.9 percent by taking 5.5 percent.
There's no question in this litigation as to the salary level for that 11 days, for appellees.
It's 12.9 percent above the previous base salary.

I do want to discuss the constitutional point a little bit more but I notice that I'm almost out of time and I do want to save some time for rebuttal, so unless the Court has any questions I'd like to reserve the balance of my time.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But your basic constitutional argument is that Congress has the power to lower the salaries of federal judges along with the salaries of other government officials as long as you can't characterize the reduction as discriminatory and as aimed at judges in a way that might threaten their independence.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: That is our argument, if the Court agrees that the--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: If we agree with you otherwise, we then must face the constitutional issue for the--

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --Well, if the Court agrees that in '76, '77, and '78 Congress acted to withdraw the Adjustment Act increases before they went into effect and that that is not a diminution, then you don't have to reach--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --I understand that, but if we agree with you?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --No.
If you agree with my opponents, that--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: No, if I agree with you, with the Government, as to the effect of all the Acts, just the way you argue, then we must face the constitutional issue on reduction.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --Only on the '79 Act.
Only as to the '79 Act, if you agree with our opponents--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I understand that.
I understand that we must... for whatever we face it, we have to face it.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --As to the '79 Act at least, that's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, and then, you've decided it.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: And our position is, as you correctly stated, Justice White, that the correct test, the test that this Court, I think, set forth in O'Malley against Woodrough, is whether the statute is meant to discriminate against Article III judges or to undermine their independence.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And you say that if it is not, the Act is constitutional?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Does not violate the Compensation Clause in the--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And you think that that's the power Congress was asserting?
On October 12, after the pay increases had gone into effect--

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --We think that--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --they thought they had reduced the salaries, at that time?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --They clearly thought they were reducing salaries prospectively, and we think that that was constitutional.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, there's a statutory question there, isn't there?
That's the issue?

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Well, there's a statutory question as to whether the '79 Act applies to the judges at all.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: You say it's there, but that's an issue in this case.
That's right.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: That's right.
Now, on the constitutional argument, those of us who don't agree with you as to when the '76 increase became effective and think it did become effective at midnight, we also--

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: Then you have--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: --have to raise the same constitutional question as we have for '79.

turn.speaker: kenneth_s_geller
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth S. Geller
turn.text: --That is correct.
In '76 and '79, at the very least.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Forde.

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: Your Honors, may it please the Court:
There won't be divided argument.
We appreciate the order the Court entered, graciously granting that permission but we have concluded that the comments can be made accurately... accurately and appropriately by counsel.
The point we--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I'm having a little difficulty hearing you.

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: --I'm sorry, Justice Brennan.

The point that we desire to make and the explanation that we think we owe the American people if not the Court in an unusual case like this, a case brought by judges in federal courts, is that it's their duty to bring such a case.
This Court has said so in the O'Donoghue decisions and in other cases.
The American Bar Association canons of ethics impose such a duty upon the judiciary, and--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What canon of ethics imposes a duty on the judiciary to file a suit urging other judges to raise their salary?

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: --Canon 1 of the American Bar Association Canons of Judicial Ethics says it's the responsibility of a judge to preserve the independence of the judiciary.
This case involves the independence of the judiciary.
I think that... and this raises exactly the point that we attempt to make.

While it's a case that does involve judges' pay, judges like Judges Campbell and Will, for example, would not have filed a lawsuit in a federal court for the comparatively few dollars that are involved in this case.

But it in their opinion presents an issue of critical constitutional moment that must be decided by this Court, because they believe that if Congress can do this... at the time they filed the suit it was only two years.
They feared they would attempt to do it again, and in fact their fears have been proven by history.
Now they've done it five years in a row.

They feared that ultimately the Solicitor General or the Department of Justice may take some position, for example, that Congress can do whatever they want to judges' salaries so long as they treat others the same way.
And such, other, such argument, that seems to be completely in contradiction to Article III.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Yet the Disqualification Act requires a judge to disqualify himself if he owns one share of stock in a corporation that is litigated before the Court.

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: That's correct.
There's an exception to the disqualification statute in the rule of necessity.
The rule of necessity... we agree fully with the Solicitor General on this point... the rule of necessity has been in effect as long as we have know it.
We've cited cases in this Court in these appeals.
We've cited cases and referred the Court to the briefs in the Atkins case.
And as long as federal courts have been sitting, there has been a rule of necessity.
There is no indication in the legislative history of this disqualification statute or any other disqualification statute, that Congress intended to change that.
And, in fact, there is testimony in legislative history before the Congress in adopting this disqualification statute that they intended to preserve the rule of necessity.

So there is no question but that any judge, including the judges of this Court, are disqualified in this appeal or that the district judge or any other district or circuit judge is disqualified from hearing these cases.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Now, and what is the rule of necessity?
Briefly, it is that if every judge is disqualified, then nobody is disqualified.

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: If every judge is disqualified, then nobody is disqualified.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It wouldn't apply, for example, if four members of this Court were for some reason or another disqualified but five were not?

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: It wouldn't apply.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: This Court couldn't act because there wouldn't be a quorum, but it wouldn't be applicable there, would it?

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: I don't know; that's an interesting question.
I don't know the answer to it.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, your rule, as I've phrased it, would not be applicable, which is that the rule of necessity is applicable only if all judges are disqualified.

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: I think there is an instance, Justice Stewart, where, if my recollection is correct, Chief Justice Stone invoked the rule by implication, at least, because the Court couldn't get a quorum.
And I think the Government cited it either in this case or the Atkins.
So I would read the rule of necessity as applying if it's necessary to get a quorum.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But in any event, in this case, every federal judge is for one reason or two reasons disqualified?

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: There's no question about that.
And there is no other place... wherever the case would be sent, there is no judge, even if he's appointed tomorrow, who wouldn't have an interest in the outcome of this case.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Yes, but the language in Evans v. Gore, which is relied on in the Court of Claims opinion and so forth, was rendered at a time when the disqualification statute didn't apply to Supreme Court Justices, so it was really dicta, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: Well, it might have been dicta but it's sound law.
The rule of necessity has been applied since 1300 or 1400.
And I think what the Evans Court was saying is just what the long established law is.

If you want to treat it as dicta, then today is the time to decide that issue, which has to be decided, and I submit has to be decided the way both we and the Solicitor General suggest it must be decided.
The result is chaos.
The contrary would be chaos.
The contrary would mean that if Congress passed a statute tomorrow saying that all judges of this Court have to resign in five years, there's no one who could challenge it.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, the other result is not particularly appealing either, is it?

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: Oh, it's not appealing, but when you look at the alternative it's not that difficult, in my judgment.
The point I was starting to make is, we feel we owe an explanation to the American people as to why federal judges sue in federal courts.
The fact of the matter is they have to because there's no other place to go and they had an oath, we felt, part of their oath of office, to bring the case.
Judge Roszkowski had an oath of office to decide the case, and I think you're in the same boat.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you think you could have brought this case and had a judgment if you'd have sued Mr. Foley, the head of the Administrative Office?
Would there have been a case or controversy between this class of judges and Mr. Foley?
Could you have proceeded on that basis rather than against the United States?

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: We thought not, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why not?

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: We thought--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I know you decided not to, but I'm... for what--

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: --We thought not, because we thought that we were suing under the Tucker Act and that says you sue the United States--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --I didn't ask... this isn't what I asked you.

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: --Well, let me get--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Could you have sued Mr. Foley and stayed in court on it?

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: --It wouldn't have... if your question suggests--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I want to know whether you could have obtained in a suit against him a declaration of unconstitutionality or constitutionality of these statutes, or have the statutes construed?
After all, Mr. Foley turned around and brought a suit himself.

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: --I don't know the answer, Justice White.
I know this--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, what if the answer was, yes?

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: --You're addressing it to solve the disqualification question?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, I am.

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: It would have no effect on that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I'm addressing the rule of necessity.

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: It would have had no effect on it because if we sued Mr. Foley instead of the United States, a federal judge having an interest in the case would have to decide it.
It doesn't make any difference who the parties are.
The fact of the matter is--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why would a federal judge have to decide it?

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: --Because it's a case brought in, it has to be brought in the federal courts.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: I don't know of any other forum to raise the constitutional question.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why not?
I mean, state courts hear federal question cases all the time.

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: We know of no jurisdictional basis for bringing this case in a state court.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, couldn't the Circuit Court of Cook County have adjudicated this case?

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Why not?

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: You can't sue the United States in the Circuit Court of Cook County.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: I'm asking, suing Mr. Foley?

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: I don't know if we could have gotten the relief against Mr. Foley.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, how can you say then that the rule of necessity applies if there were some judges in the United States who could hear the case?

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: I think we could--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: After all, it's been argued, and certainly some state courts have entertained 1983 suits.

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: --This isn't a 1983 case.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I know it is not a 1983 case but I'm just suggesting to you that state courts decide federal questions all the time.

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: I know of no basis upon which we could have obtained the relief that we sought in this case in any state courts.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Well, what are you saying?
That you couldn't get personal jurisdiction over Mr. Foley?

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: That may have been a problem.
I simply don't know of any basis upon which we could sue him.
I think also the point is that suits against officials are deemed suits against the United States.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, in any event, in this case there's no question about the fact that in this case, which is the case you did bring, every federal judge in the United States has got a financial interest.

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: That's right.
I believe, then, I've made the point why we felt this case had to be brought, why the plaintiffs felt this case had to be brought.
I'd like next to address the arguments that are raised.

The most important point, I think, that has to be discussed is the contention of the Solicitor General and the Department of Justice in these cases that a judge cannot prove a violation of Article III, Section 1, without showing, proving discrimination.
I guess this takes us to to where the statutes are, what the Constitution provides.
The Constitution provides, in very unequivocal terms, that a judge is to receive a compensation which shall not be diminished.
Mr. Geller opened his comments by saying that these were complex statutes.
These are about as simple and unequivocal as statutes as appear on the books.
Not a one of them exceeds more than a few lines that are relevant here.
Section 135 provides a salary for a district judge.
The language of the other statutes for other judges are in the same language.
One-thirty-five provides that a district judge shall receive a salary at a rate determined under the Salary Act, as has been discussed, as adjusted by the Adjustment Act.
The Salary Act, of course, is the provision for the quadrennial raises on those few occasions that Congress permits them to go ahead.
And I might add that the system has now been changed so that it requires an affirmative vote in both houses before a raise can go into effect under the Salary Act.

But the Adjustment Act, which is the principal act at issue here, provides in very unequivocal terms... and the relevant portions are again about two lines long... it provides that for each fiscal year judges' salaries shall be adjusted in an amount equal to the percentage adjustment granted general schedule employees.

Incidentally, none of the statutes that have been referred to that are intended to prevent that adjustment, including the one adopted in July, 1977, ever mention any intent to repeal or modify or amend the rights under the Adjustment Act.
The Adjustment Act applies to all executive level employees except with respect to judges.
That section says, it can never be downward.
There was a question earlier about whether the adjustment under the Comparability Act can be a downward adjustment--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: It can, as to other employees.

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: --As to other employees, there can be a downward adjustment.
As to judges, there never can be.
Until these cases were brought and until this recent history by Congress, the Compensation Clause has always been honored by Congress.
Even in the Great Depression when the salaries of other federal employees were reduced and reduced and reduced for good reason, Congress never tampered with judges' pay.
Now, there were income tax cases.
Atkins involved a question of whether judges who were suffering from inflation were entitled to an increase because they weren't receiving compensation, in real dollars, the same as prior years.
But when it come to the basic salary statutes, 28 U.S.C. 135 and the prior statutes like that, Congress never made any attempt to tamper with those statutes.
The only thing that came anywhere near it was the Booth case, which we decided, and that was... and there they attempted to cut the pay of a retired judge.
And the Department of Justice said, in that case a retired judge is not an Article III judge.
This Court, the Supreme Court, the Court at that time, decided that he was an Article III judge.
The Solicitor General in that case said, if he is an Article III judge, we concede that his compensation may not be cut... even in this time of depression.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: When you say compensation, then, you're talking about United States dollars, in effect?

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: No, in this case we are talking about the salaries set by the salary acts, the Salary Act, the Adjustment Act, and 28 U.S.C. Section 135 for judges.
That is a judge's pay, and it is our position that that may not be reduced.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Okay, but what if the Congress decided that the Court would only be allocated one car, instead of two or three or whatever it has, next year.
And--

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: Or parking space?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --Or parking space.
Would that be called diminution of compensation?

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: I don't know.
There are a number of things like that you could explore.
I don't know how far compensation goes.
I know it includes at least this much, the salary of a judge as provided by the Salary Act and Adjustment Act and 28 U.S.C. 135.
How much farther it goes isn't before the Court today.
But it's certainly our reading of the word compensation, as an academic inquiry, would indicate, me to believe, that it's much broader than just that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Under the Comparability Act, though, the report is to the President and then the President makes a recommendation to Congress?

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And then either house of Congress can disapprove it?

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: They can, but the result of their disapproval--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is it goes back to the President.

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: --Is, it goes back to the President or, automatically, accepts the report of the President's agent.
They get a... the general schedule employees--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You mean Congress... under the terms of the Comparability Act, you are asserting Congress has no power to keep a recommended increase from going into effect?

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: --That's right.
They can reject the President's, but the effect of their rejection of the President would be to put into effect the higher recommendation of the President's agent.
In other words, like this year, the President's agent said that the appropriate adjustment for federal employees would be 13-some percent, as I recall.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, what if the President doesn't take the recommendation of his agent?

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: He didn't.
He said, 9.1.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: All right.
And so say he... say the agent recommends 13 percent, the President comes in with ten.

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Congress rejects it.
The Government's brief says,
"In that event the President must again consider the report of his agent and adjust the rates of pay in accordance with the principles of comparability. "

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: Yes.
What they're saying is--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: All right, suppose he does, and the Congress rejects it again?

turn.speaker: kevin_m_forde
turn.label: Mr. Kevin M. Forde
turn.text: --I don't know.
I don't think they get two turns.
